text.p: Here are highlights of stories in Romania's press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
Business:
ADEVARUL
- The financial police recouped 425 billion lei from bad tax payers.
- The Agriculture Ministry plans to issue a draft bill on insurance in the farming sector.
- Heavy rains and hail killed seven people and damaged crops on some 60,000 hectares last week, the paper said.
- Romania's state airline Tarom plans to sell its Soviet-made planes through the Bucharest commodities exchange.
CURIERUL NATIONAL
- Damage caused by bad weather last week amounts to some 100 billion lei, Agriculture Minister Dinu Gavrilescu is quoted as saying.
General:
ROMANIA LIBERA

- Romania will go on with its reforms, irrespective of NATO's decision in July to invite Romania to join the Alliance in the first wave of enlargement, Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea said during a visit to Washington.

- President Emil Constantinescu apologised in the name of the Romanian state to the victims of Communism for the horrors of communist-era repression, in a first act of contrition by a Romanian leader since Communism fell in 1989.
- Constantinescu recommends that the government should hold regular talks with the opposition.
EVENIMENTUL ZILEI

- Five leading politicians and MPs -- among which former foreign minister Teodor Melescanu and former reform minister Mircea Cosea -- left the main opposition Party of Social Democracy (PDSR) saying the party had failed to restructure.
- Ex-president Ion Iliescu was re-elected PDSR leader at the party's national conference at the weekend.
- U.S. President Bill Clinton perseveres in denying support to Romania's bid to get early NATO admission, the paper says.
- Italian police caught two Romanians trying to smuggle four kilos of cocaine out of Milan airport and into Romania.
ADEVARUL
- Clinton rejected France's, Italy's and Canada's pleas for Romania's integration into NATO in a first wave of admissions, the newspaper says.

-The ruling coalition sees cooperation with the five reformist leading politicians who resigned from PDSR as possible. National Peasant Party (PNT-CD) leader Ion Diaconescu said he would welcome the five as PNT-CD members if they applied for membership.
-- Bucharest Newsroom 40-1 3120264
